令人惊叹的夜间街头摄影的 12 个技巧（+常见问题解答）首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是詹姆斯·马赫。

本文于 James Maher 和 Jaymes Dempsey 的贡献下于 2024 年 2 月更新。

我喜欢在晚上进行街头摄影。这座城市被无数有趣且色彩缤纷的光源照亮，如灯柱、霓虹灯、商店橱窗、汽车灯和裸露的灯泡。人们穿着自己喜欢的衣服四处走动。白天看似平淡的场景在天黑后变得不祥而迷人。

但捕捉美丽的夜间街头摄影可能很困难。您必须选择正确的设置、应对相机抖动、找到完美的拍摄对象等等。足以让任何人头疼！

幸运的是，我多年来一直从事夜间街头摄影。随着时间的推移，我学到了很多技巧、技​​巧和智慧，可以提高任何人的夜间街头拍摄能力。我测试了不同的设置，确定了如何处理夜间照明，并且学会了如何保持安全。

因此，要了解我的顶级街头夜间摄影技巧 - 并学习如何即使在黑暗中也能捕捉华丽的图像 - 请继续阅读！

夜间街拍照片的最佳相机设置

在夜间（或任何时候，真的！）捕捉清晰的街头照片主要取决于快门速度，所以这就是我想开始的地方。

为了定格白天的运动，我更喜欢使用 1/320 秒的快门速度（以 1/160 秒作为我的下限）。但到了晚上，情况就会发生变化。在最亮的区域（路灯或汽车前灯照明），您可以轻松地以 1/250 秒的速度进行拍摄，但大多数时候，您需要使用 1/60 秒到 1/160 秒之间的快门速度。否则，您将被迫将 ISO 提高到荒谬的高度，并且您将面临因噪点而毁掉图像的风险。

请注意，当快门速度设置为 1/60 秒时，您需要稳定的双手。 （具有图像稳定功能的镜头或相机可以提供帮助；幸运的是，现在大多数像样的无反光镜相机都配备了机身图像稳定功能，并且大多数镜头也都具有！）请注意，要以 1/60 秒手持拍摄，您需要完全停止自己的动作。幸运的是，通过一些练习，这是可以做到的——只需确保在按下快门按钮时始终注意手部动作即可。

至于夜间街头摄影的最佳光圈设置：光圈越大，快门速度就越快（或者ISO可以降低得越低）。在夜间较亮的区域可以使用 f/4 进行拍摄，但如果您可以使用 f/2.8、f/2 甚至 f/1.8 进行拍摄，那么拍摄会轻松很多。换句话说，夜间街头摄影的光圈越大越好。 （也就是说，较宽的光圈有一个主要缺点：景深极浅。因此，正如我在下面解释的那样，您需要非常仔细地对焦，以避免产生大量失焦的镜头。）

最后，您需要将 ISO 提高到 1600、3200 甚至 6400。使用现代数码相机，您可以在高 ISO 下拍摄并拍摄出不错的图像，但最好保持 ISO 尽可能低，否则您将无法在夜间拍摄出曝光良好的照片。 （我个人使用 ISO 3200 进行拍摄，有时在特别黑暗的区域或拍摄快速移动的物体时，我会使用 ISO 6400。）此外，夜间的颗粒状照片看起来效果出奇的好；砂砾增加了美感，尤其是当你转换为黑白时。

您应该使用什么相机模式？如果您在各种不同的照明场景（即进出路灯）中进行快节奏拍摄，光圈优先可以很好地发挥作用 - 只需将相机设置为最大光圈和最高可容忍 ISO，然后让它为您选择快门速度。 （如果快门速度低于 1/60 秒，那么您要么需要接受一些模糊，进一步提高 ISO，要么在光线较多的区域拍摄。）

至于对焦方法：通常情况下，区域对焦是街头摄影的好方法，但在夜间使用超广角光圈时，您最终会丢失很多图像。如果您可以提前预测拍摄，您可以尝试使用手动对焦在某个区域进行预对焦，但使用连续自动对焦和相机的跟踪模式之一可能是更好的选择，具体取决于相机的功能。 （如果您不确定什么最有效，请尝试做一些实验！）

夜间街头摄影的必备装备

最好的夜间街头摄影装备与白天街头摄影装备大致相似，因为您希望您的设备轻便、紧凑且不引人注目。也就是说，在为夜间探险购买新设备时需要记住以下几点：

选择具有良好高 ISO 功能的相机

由于您经常会在 ISO 3200、ISO 6400 甚至更高的感光度下进行拍摄，因此使用不会因噪音爆炸而破坏您的照片的街头摄影相机至关重要。考虑投资紧凑型全画幅相机或一流的 APS-C 型号，并尽量将百万像素数保持在较低水平，因为与普通相机相比，超高 MP 相机在高 ISO 下拍摄时实际上往往表现更差MP 较低的兄弟姐妹（假设该技术来自同一代）。

低光对焦功能也非常方便——许多相机很难在黑暗中对焦，而其他相机则在这方面表现出色。如果您的相机无法在近乎黑暗的情况下对焦，这并不是绝对的问题——您可以手动对焦或在路灯下拍摄——但这肯定会限制您的灵活性。

选择最大光圈较宽的镜头

正如我上面提到的，您需要确保选择一款紧凑型镜头来拍摄夜间街道。但是，虽然大多数白天街头摄影都是在 f/8 左右的光圈下拍摄的，但夜间则是完全不同的情况。您需要将镜头的光圈扩大到最大，这意味着镜头提供的最大光圈越宽越好。

因此，我建议使用最大光圈至少为 f/2.8 的镜头（假设模型仍然相对紧凑，f/1.8 或 f/1.4 可能更好）。

它还可以帮助您获得比您可能倾向于使用的更宽的定焦镜头，例如 35 毫米、28 毫米，或者（如果您对更独特的外观感兴趣）24 毫米。广角镜头不易出现相机抖动，而且在夜间也更容易使用，因为黑暗和缺乏活动会减少整个场景中的干扰。

当然，您仍然可以使用标准 50 毫米镜头进行夜间街头摄影 - 例如，50 毫米 f/1.8 几乎适合所有街头摄影场景 - 但如果您有机会使用广角镜头，我建议您在至少测试一下！

夜间街头摄影的 10 个技巧

现在您已经了解了夜间拍摄街道的最佳设置和设备，让我们看一下针对初学者和高级街头拍摄者的一些技巧，以提高您的拍摄效果。

1.寻找光源

始终注意场景中的主要光源。无论您在何时何地拍摄，这一点都是如此，但在夜间变得更加重要。因此，与其寻找拍摄对象，不如从寻找美丽的光源或照明良好的区域开始，然后等待事情发生。

请注意，夜间街头摄影照明可以是任何东西：汽车头灯、路灯、霓虹灯、窗户照明，甚至智能手机灯。只需寻找明显的照明，然后仔细注意这些光源如何照射到潜在的拍摄对象即可。调整角度，直到获得您想要的灯光效果，然后拍摄！

当我拍摄纽约市的街道时，我发现了一家窗户明亮的漂亮餐厅。我利用餐厅灯光来呈现路人的细节：

2. 多拍几张照片

有时，街头摄影师喜欢使用更谨慎的方法，只拍摄每个主题的几张图像。这在白天效果很好，特别是如果您可以自信地确定焦点和曝光，但在晚上，这会导致许多失败的图像。

因此，当您晚上外出时，不要只为每个主题或场景拍摄一两张图像，而是要稍微推动一下。不要害怕拍摄同一主题的 5-10 张照片，如果您愿意稍后对所有照片进行排序，您甚至可以考虑使用相机的连拍模式在几秒钟内拍摄数十张照片。

这里的想法只是最大化你成功的机会。你拍摄的次数越多，你就越有可能抓住拍摄对象移动得足够慢以保持锐利的那一刻，即使是在 1/60 秒的情况下也是如此——而且即使在极薄的景深下，你也更有可能抓住焦点。场地。

3.拍摄夜生活

城市的某些地方——比如商业区——在晚上可能会空无一人。它们会带来糟糕的夜间街头摄影体验。然而，其他地区在日落后会变得更加繁忙，并且会提供大量机会。

所以寻找夜生活并拍摄吧！您可以考虑在互联网上搜索您所在地区的酒吧和俱乐部，然后确保在夜晚开始时前往。或者，如果您想要更正式的主题，可以去一些高档餐厅附近散步，看看能找到什么！

并且不要觉得您仅限于在俱乐部和餐馆外的街道上拍摄人们。您可以通过窗户拍摄来捕捉各种令人惊叹的效果（此外，如果您对拍摄人物感到有点紧张，窗户可以充当障碍并减少您的焦虑）。

4. 交替靠近和后退

我非常支持罗伯特·卡帕的建议：“如果你的照片不够好，那是因为你离得不够近。”然而，我经常在晚上违反这个规则。

你看，虽然我确实尝试接近我的许多主题 - 我鼓励你也这样做 - 我也尝试创作其中主题是整个场景的小方面的构图。晚上，背景可能比白天漂亮得多，因此让人物成为场景中的次要元素而不是主要焦点通常是值得的。

这种方法具有技术优势：当拍摄对象位于远处时，您无需使用较快的快门速度来捕捉他们的动作。附近的拍摄对象可以以 1/125 秒或更快的速度冻结；通常可以用 1/60 秒拍摄远处的物体，即使它在移动，也能拍出清晰的效果。

5. 尝试使用三脚架以获得创意效果

在进行街头夜间摄影时，通常最好手持。毕竟，你永远不知道会发生什么有趣的事情，并且你希望能够快速做出反应。

也就是说，带上三脚架会很有用，特别是如果您有兴趣拍摄一些长时间曝光的街头摄影。

这里的想法是找到一个繁忙的区域，将相机安装在三脚架上，然后使用慢快门速度捕捉运动中的人物。您需要尝试不同的快门速度（1/8 秒是一个很好的起点），并且您需要拍摄大量照片，但最终会得到一些华丽的运动模糊效果：

我花了很长时间才捕捉到上面显示的图像；我希望人物遍布整个场景，我还想要一个有趣的前景主题（最后，我对街上的女人和看着她的男人的姿势感到满意）。

6.尝试使用闪光灯

一些街头摄影师喜欢使用闪光灯，而另一些则讨厌它。是否决定在夜间尝试闪光灯取决于您；一方面，它会提供额外的照明，因此您可以使用更快的快门速度、更窄的光圈和更低的 ISO。另一方面，它会给人一种非常强烈的车头灯下的鹿的感觉，而且它可能会导致对抗（人们不喜欢被闪光，尤其是在黑暗中！）。

就我个人而言，我更喜欢在自然光的限制下工作，而且在黑暗环境中闪烁的陌生人也会让我感到不舒服。但如果您有足够的信心使用闪光灯拍摄，那么请务必尝试一下，看看您的想法。如果做得好的话，它可以呈现出美妙的外观。

请注意，您可以让闪光灯完成照亮场景的所有工作（以便前景区域变亮而背景完全黑暗）。但您也可以将相机设置为稍微曝光不足的场景，然后使用闪光灯为前景中的主要拍摄对象添加一些补光。

7. 增加曝光时要小心

当使用高 ISO 拍摄时，确定曝光很重要；这样，您在编辑时就不会被迫增加亮度，否则会夸大令人不快的噪点效果。

话虽这么说，您偶尔会遇到意外拍摄曝光不足的情况。当这种情况发生时，你别无选择，只能在编辑时提高曝光度。只要确保你小心翼翼地做就可以了。

这是我的建议：首先，忽略噪音并获得曝光并看起来正确。如果您必须大幅提高曝光度，噪点将会很严重，因此您需要应用一些降噪措施。

有很多优秀的降噪程序，但我喜欢 Lightroom 内置的降噪功能。如果应用降噪算法后噪点仍然很严重，请尝试将图像带入Photoshop中添加非常轻微的高斯模糊。

那时，我经常使用 Lightroom 的颗粒设置将纹理添加回照片中。结果看起来比极端的数字噪声更悦目，并且它可以隐藏曝光不足图像的一些技术缺陷。照片看起来不会非常清晰，但仍然很漂亮。

8. 不要害怕模糊和不完美

大多数街头摄影师的目标是让他们的照片尽可能清晰。清晰度当然不是坏事 - 但要知道，即使照片不是非常清晰，它仍然可以看起来很棒。

您会发现，在夜间拍摄时，您不需要完美地冻结运动即可获得令人惊叹的结果。就我个人而言，我对白天图像的要求高于夜间图像的标准。我的白天图像需要看起来清晰，而我的夜间照片只需要有趣且看起来不错，即使有些地方有点模糊。

此外，在 1/60 秒到 1/30 秒左右的快门速度下，手持拍摄会很有趣。你的拍摄对象会显得有些尖锐，但也会有一些运动。这是为您的作品增添活力的好方法。

9.让你的夜间街拍照片看起来很暗

在我看来，夜景拍摄应该看起来像在晚上拍摄的。它们应该是黑暗的，有很深的阴影和难以看到的区域。当您查看夜间图像的直方图时，它应该向最左侧倾斜，尤其是相对于白天图像而言。

但是，当您将相机对准夜间的街景时，照片通常会曝光过度。生成的文件看起来很明亮，您将能够看到大量细节，但场景感觉不真实。 （您最终还会看到路灯和商店橱窗被吹坏。）在这种情况下，您需要稍微降低相机的曝光补偿，或者 - 如果您在手动模式下拍摄 - 提高快门速度，缩小光圈，或扩大 ISO。

我确实认为明亮的夜间图像看起来不错。但黑暗、逼真的夜间图像通常更好，因此请仔细监控直方图，不要害怕根据需要放弃曝光补偿。

10. 在恶劣天气下拍摄

当天气变坏时，冒险进入夜间可能会令人畏惧。 （我从个人经验中知道这一点！）然而，正是这些条件——雪、雨、雾和雨夹雪——可以将普通的街景变成一张充满气氛和情感的照片。想象一下雪花在路灯的照耀下旋转，或者一个有雾的夜晚，黑暗的人影进出建筑物。这些元素引入了一层复杂性和情绪，在晴朗的天空下很难复制。

也就是说，接受恶劣天气确实意味着面临一些挑战。夜间气温通常会下降，降水会增加体温过低的风险；因此，即使是夏天的街头摄影，当下雨时也会感到不舒服甚至危险。另外，保持相机干燥可能很麻烦，在最坏的情况下，您甚至可能损坏您的设备。

幸运的是，通过适当的准备，您（通常）可以预防这些问题。穿着保暖——想想外套、帽子、手套——并多穿几层衣服让自己保持舒适。对于您的相机来说，一个简单的防雨罩就可以成为您的救星。我还建议带一个火箭吹风机（这样你可以清除前镜头元件上的水滴）和一条小毛巾（这样你可以定期擦拭相机和镜筒）。无论您做什么，都不要忘记遮光罩；否则，降水会很快覆盖您的镜头并破坏您的图像。

还有一件事：在夜间恶劣天气下拍摄是很困难的，并且接受并非每一个镜头都会成为杰作是这个过程的一部分。夜间和恶劣的天气条件可能难以预测，但它们也为独特的摄影机会打开了大门。如果您愿意拍摄大量照片，那么您很可能会至少捕获几个饲养员。这一切都需要耐心、毅力和一点冒险精神！

11.小心

这个技巧是绝对必要的，但也很难写。您会发现，根据拍摄地点的不同，晚上携带相机外出并不总是最安全的主意。另一方面，许多地区在夜间比您想象的要安全，尤其是在傍晚。

因此，不要因为害怕晚上拍摄而不敢出门，但也要确保自己的安全。轻装出行，尽量减少携带的装备，并小心出行。确保注意周围环境，如果您开始感到不舒服，请转向另一个方向。

如果您不确定晚上是否可以安全地在街上拍照，请做一些研究。我建议向该地区的资深街头射击者发送消息，不过您也可以查看有关城市犯罪率的一般文章和统计数据。

使用您对拍摄对象的最佳判断，并考虑带一位朋友一起去。不要在一个地方停留太久，也不要放下装备去更换镜头。最后，如果您希望更加安心，请在出发前为您的装备做好保险！

12. 专注于你的编辑技巧

夜间街头摄影具有挑战性的照明条件通常意味着您的图像需要进行一些后期处理才能真正闪耀 - 这就是您的编辑技能发挥作用的地方。我强烈建议购买（或订阅）专用的照片编辑程序；它将为您提供创建专业级图像所需的工具，虽然一开始学习曲线可能有点大，但您不需要很长时间就能掌握基本技术。

刚开始时，请特别注意白平衡和曝光。调整这些元素，直到获得自然、美观的结果。最初，您可能会发现自己来回滑动控件，进行试验，直到发出咔嗒声。完全没问题；根据我的经验，这个试错阶段可以培养你寻找有效方法的眼睛。

当您对可用的工具越来越熟悉时，您将开始欣赏细微调整的力量。您甚至可以开始开发某些编辑首选项，您可以将其烘焙到您自己的预设中。 （顺便说一句，创建预设可以简化编辑过程，而且它们可以使您的作品集更轻松地获得一致的结果！）

但旅程并没有就此结束。一旦掌握了基础知识，就可以尝试使用颜色分级等更高级的技术了。这可以为您的图像增添风格，真正让您的作品与众不同。通过练习，你会发现剪辑成为你摄影的自然延伸，你可以用它来表达你对夜间城市景观的独特视角！

夜间拍摄街道的优点和缺点

夜间街头摄影有几个主要好处 - 换句话说，它受欢迎是有原因的！

首先，街道在晚上往往比较空旷，让你可以毫无困难地隔离一两个拍摄对象——这可以拍出更强大的简约镜头。

在夜间用路灯拍摄也会给图像增添不同的情绪，给人一种神秘、怀旧、戏剧甚至恐怖的感觉，具体取决于你的拍摄方式。

崭露头角的街头摄影师——甚至更有成就的摄影师——在拍摄陌生人时有时会因恐惧或不适而挣扎。然而，晚上工作会给人一种距离感和匿名感，从而减少焦虑。

当然，夜间街头摄影面临着一些重大挑战。相机依靠光线来捕捉清晰、曝光良好的图像，尤其是夜间——您无疑已经知道了！ – 没有提供太多的光线。为了解决这个问题，真正掌握相机技术非常重要。否则，您最终会得到模糊、颗粒状或黑暗（或三者组合）的图像。

正如我上面强调的，在某些地区夜间拍摄确实很危险。显然，这取决于位置，也取决于您采取的方法。下面，我提供了在夜间采取适当安全预防措施的提示，但记住这一点确实很重要，这样您就不会毫无准备。

晚上拍摄街道安全吗？

这实际上取决于位置和您的方法。夜间街头摄影相对安全，但风险始终存在，因此需要谨慎并采取适当的预防措施。

晚上的街头值得拍照吗？

我想是这样！夜晚的街道看起来非常神奇，呈现出一种全新的形象。

夜间街拍的最佳 ISO 是多少？

我建议在不产生令人难以置信的噪音的情况下将 ISO 调得尽可能高。您需要高 ISO 才能获得相当快的快门速度，而且夜间拍摄时噪点看起来也不错。

美丽的室内建筑摄影的 11 个专家技巧帖子首先出现在数码摄影学校。它的作者是杰布·布赫曼。

本文于 Jeb Buchman、 Natalia Robert和Lily Sawyer的贡献下于 2024 年 2 月更新。

室内建筑摄影是一项广受欢迎的技能；您可以使用它来创建引人注目的房地产照片、企业图像、令人惊叹的大教堂照片，甚至历史纪实照片。但拍摄室内场景并不完全是在公园散步。它面临着很多挑战，包括狭窄的空间、低光照和困难的拍摄技术。

幸运的是，我花了数年时间磨练我的室内建筑拍摄技巧，在这篇文章中，我分享了确保成功的重要技巧。我讨论：

  • 室内建筑的最佳焦距
  • 你绝对必须拥有的装备
  • 改善作文的简单方法
  • 简单的编辑步骤即可获得精致的结果
  • 多得多！

因此，如果您准备好提升室内拍摄水平，那么就让我们开始吧。

1. 如果可能的话，准备好空间

如果您要拍摄房屋或企业的内部空间，我强烈建议您花时间整理和开放空间来做好准备。清理所有平坦表面和地板区域。打开所有百叶窗和窗帘。清洁水槽中的所有脏盘子并将其收起来。一定要比自己清洁更多的空间。我们习惯了杂乱，并对它视而不见，但照片中的一点杂乱会立即变得明显。

完成后，这个空间应该让人感觉很吸引人，就像你想象自己生活或工作的地方一样。但如果您完成清洁后仍然没有留下深刻的印象，您可以通过添加个人风格在照片中营造出这种感觉。

如果有餐桌，可容纳两人，并在中央放一瓶鲜花。通过添加报纸、咖啡杯和一盘或一碗清淡（漂亮）的小吃，将空荡荡的早餐角变成一个休息的好地方。将蓬松的浴袍挂在浴缸旁边的挂钩上。

如果有桌子，请考虑添加一台工作笔记本电脑和一本书（或三本书）。当谈到装饰或调色板时，您要么想让空间充满个性以发挥其独特性，要么用流行的明亮色彩保持一切中性。

2. 始终使用三脚架

每当你拍摄建筑内部时，你绝对必须使用三脚架。这主要有以下几个原因：

首先，三脚架可以稳定您的相机/镜头设置，从而大大减少相机抖动的可能性。由于室内拍摄往往是在窄光圈和慢快门速度下拍摄的，因此为相机提供坚如磐石的支撑至关重要。

其次，如果您使用三脚架，则更容易确保相机水平。 （虽然我稍后会在本文中讨论水平相机的重要性，但它几乎是所有建筑摄影的基本组成部分。）

此外，在拍摄室内场景时没有充分的理由不使用三脚架。当然，如果您正在跟踪拍摄对象或需要不断地动态改变位置，那么三脚架就会成为障碍。但建筑摄影是缓慢而深思熟虑的；由于您的主题是建筑物，因此当您设置相机、拨入各种设置并微调构图时，您始终可以指望它能够保持良好的静止状态。

请注意，室内拍摄往往很少有风、急流或雨水，因此您通常可以使用更便宜的三脚架（尽管也有理由投资一个坚固的模型，包括装备安全，所以请确保您请仔细选择您的型号！）。

3.从自然光开始

建筑摄影，尤其是室内建筑摄影的优点之一是没有任何东西移动。您可以通过调整设置（尤其是快门速度）来利用这一点。

将相机固定在三脚架上，您可以调低快门速度来捕捉所有环境光，即使在非常黑暗的角落也是如此。如果一些灯具和灯光增添了房间的整体氛围，请将它们包括在内，并利用慢快门速度和长时间曝光。

重要的是要记住，对于室内装饰，您应该以平衡照明为目标；换句话说，不应有过暗的阴影或过亮的高光。您希望看到黑暗区域的细节，但又不想完全掩盖明亮区域。并考虑一天中的哪些时间最能体现室内空间的特色。清晨和傍晚的光线非常柔和，但阴天也会产生柔和的光线。

另一方面，明亮的超级晴天会产生更刺眼的光线，尤其是中午左右。因此，您可能需要考虑刺眼的外部光线在室内产生的阴影。如果您正在创建美术图像，则可以使用这些阴影作为艺术元素，但如果您正在进行商业摄影，这可能不合适。

4. 尽可能使用闪光灯

在上一篇技巧中，我强调了自然光的价值。但是，虽然您的目标应该是获得尽可能多的自然光，但如果您在没有闪光灯的情况下拍摄房间，通常会在房间周围散布阴影（由沿墙壁和天花板不同位置放置的人工照明引起）。这通常看起来不太好，并且从曝光的角度来看可能很难处理，所以我鼓励您使用一点闪光灯。您只需要一两个热靴灯或闪光灯，它们将有助于平衡整个画面的曝光。

这是我的建议：

确保您的闪光灯安装在单独的三脚架或支架上（它们不应该安装在您的相机上！），并将它们放置在离相机一侧几英尺、相机后面一英尺左右的地方。 （如果您使用两个闪光灯，请确保它们位于相对的两侧。）瞄准闪光灯，使它们指向天花板并稍微远离您正在拍摄的房间。

手动将闪光灯设置为半功率（低于全功率）并闪光。给定角度后，闪光灯发出的光将间接照亮房间（即从天花板和墙壁反射），您将为正在拍摄的房间获得柔和、均匀的补光。

我总是鼓励您在相机的液晶显示屏上查看生成的图像并进行相应的更改。注意奇怪的阴影、太亮的墙壁、黑暗的角落以及窗户和其他玻璃物体上闪光灯的反射。

5. 拍摄整个房间时，不要太宽

当我第一次开始拍摄建筑内部照片时，我使用了我能找到的最广角镜头。我认为使用超广角镜头，我可以在画面中获得更多的空间 - 但虽然我在技术上是正确的，但更多并不总是更好。我很快就注意到画面边缘的畸变程度很高，尤其是在较小的房间中，并且我确定超广角焦距（即 14 毫米）会使画面的侧面看起来奇怪地拉伸并偏离水平面，即使在后期制作中修正时。

所以我尝试了不同的焦距，发现21mm到28mm之间的有效焦距可以给你一个很好的平衡；在 25 毫米时，您可以获得有限的失真和足够宽的画面来捕捉场景的特征和存在。

一种选择是购买 24 毫米定焦镜头，当您刚开始使用时，这可能非常划算（大多数制造商都以低廉的价格提供高质量的 24 毫米镜头）。或者，您也可以投资购买 24-70 毫米变焦镜头 - 是的，它会花费更多，但它将提供额外的灵活性，甚至允许您在 50-70 毫米范围内捕捉一些漂亮的细节镜头。如果您确实喜欢更广阔的视角，则可以考虑使用 16-35 毫米变焦镜头。

首先将相机垂直安装在三脚架上。许多摄影师认为最好水平拍摄全景照片，但垂直方向会给你一个更高的图像。

8. 取得平衡

构图时，将观众的注意力集中在您想要的地方。如果可以的话，考虑使用舞台项目来增加前景的深度和兴趣。通过对比前景、中景和背景中的不同元素来避免照片显得单调。记住要以平衡为目标，而不是分散注意力。

使用背景来显示连通的房间也是给观众一种空间感的好方法。这将增加兴趣并使观看者感觉他们可以想象在建筑物中行走。

您还可以使用滑到相机热靴上的气泡水平仪。 （当小气泡居中时，这意味着您的相机处于水平状态。）您只需几美元就可以在几乎任何摄影商店购买这些水平仪之一，这是我的首选解决方案，因为它往往比内置的更准确 -在相机级别）。

10. 获得正确的白平衡

这是很棘手的，也是许多摄影师的克星。大多数非摄影师都忽视了白平衡。 （这一点在婚礼照片中尤其明显，新娘的裙子看起来是蓝色的，人们的脸呈洋红色，但几乎没有人注意到！）

几年前，当我卖掉我的房子时，那些自诩拥有出色的房产摄影技术的房地产经纪人派了一位摄影师到我家拍摄一些专业照片。她到达时，相机架在三脚架上，闪光灯头稍微朝上。使用的镜头非常宽——我猜大约是 10 毫米或 14 毫米。当照片上传时，我沮丧地发现照片都很蓝。我的家感觉很冷，原因之一就是白平衡不正确。

就我个人而言，我更喜欢为所有照片添加温暖的感觉，因此我倾向于在编辑过程中添加这种感觉。你可以选择中性的外观——在现场使用灰卡会有所帮助——或者你可以强调温暖，但如果你尝试后一种方法，请注意白色仍然是白色的，而不是黄色或奶油色的。

底线：永远记住，吸引人们注意图像的是一种感觉或情感。如果你的图像能让观看者想起某种情感、经历或与他们产生共鸣的事物，它就会变得更加强大。 白平衡是帮助观众实现这种互动的关键。

11. 仔细编辑你的室内图像

如果不编辑你的建筑照片，结果将会平淡无奇。因此，我鼓励您编辑您计划分享的每张图像！

首先将照片导入您最喜欢的编辑程序，然后按照这些基本编辑步骤创建更精致的结果。 （请注意，我引用了 Lightroom Classic，但您几乎可以在任何编辑器中实现相同的效果。）

理顺线条

这样做会立即美化您的照片。如果您在距地面大约五英尺的高度拍摄并保持相机水平，则需要校正的伸直量应该是最小的。在 Lightroom 中，您可以在“镜头校正”面板中找到拉直选项。

填充并均匀光线

在对亮度或曝光进行任何调整之前，请务必纠正任何镜头渐晕。 （这是图像的角落有点暗的情况，对于广角镜头尤其常见。）Lightroom 提供的镜头配置文件会自动考虑镜头的光学并进行自动校正；只需确保在“镜头校正”面板中选中“启用配置文件校正”即可。

如果您不喜欢 Lightroom 的自动调整，您可以随时进入“手动”选项卡并使用滑块来实现您预想的效果。

修正边角后，使用画笔修正明亮或黑暗区域的曝光。这是你躲避和燃烧的时间。我发现过度曝光会给空间带来更自然的感觉。我建议慢慢提高整体曝光度，当感觉太亮时，开始拉低曝光度。

您还可以使用“基本”面板中的“阴影”滑块稍微调亮黑暗区域。但是，请注意不要将阴影调得太亮，以免产生颗粒（噪点）或使图像看起来很假。

执行颜色校正

根据需要调整整体色温。如果你和我一样喜欢暖色调的效果，那就选择暖色调，而不是明显的黄色。

另外，稍微调高“鲜艳度”滑块，而不是弄乱“饱和度”滑块。添加饱和度可以很快使照片看起来太假，而自然饱和度是一种更微妙的工具，有助于给颜色带来一点额外的效果。再次，使用这些设置上的滑块；看看你的眼睛对什么感到舒服，这对磨练你的色彩校正技巧大有帮助。

调整清晰度和锐度

提高清晰度滑块，但要缓慢。清晰度是美化照片而又不过度强调对比度的好方法，而且它还能使照片整体呈现清晰的外观。根据图像的不同，您可能还想同时稍微减小黑色滑块。

您可能还想添加一些锐化（在“详细信息”面板中）。但请注意不要将“金额”滑块推得太远；您想要一个看起来详细的图像，而不是一个充满令人不快的光晕的图像。

通过克隆和治愈来清理场景

使用编辑程序的修复工具去除照片上可能出现的灰尘点或其他异常情况。

Lightroom 提供了几个选项：克隆、修复和内容感知删除。修复小斑点时，修复是一个很好的选择，因为它会产生更柔和的混合，但我喜欢使用克隆工具来消除任何眩光或反射。如果需要，您还可以使用它来删除地址号码。

顺便说一句，虽然我通常使用 Lightroom 来编辑照片，但我个人更喜欢使用 Photoshop 的图章工具进行克隆。它似乎可以更好地控制画笔本身，因此更容易以看起来自然的方式进行克隆。

室内建筑摄影技巧：最后的话

拍摄室内场景常常会遇到困难，并且擅长室内摄影并不总是那么容易。

然而，通过我上面分享的技巧加上一些练习，您很快就能拍摄出令人惊叹的照片！请记住，永远不要匆忙拍摄图像。建筑摄影的一大优点是你的拍摄对象永远不会移动，所以你有时间真正放慢速度并刻意完善每张照片。

文章《Lightroom 预览的 6 种类型（以及如何使用它们）》首先出现在Digital Photography School上。它的作者是安德鲁·S·吉布森。

Lightroom 预览是编辑工作流程的重要组成部分。但预览类型如此之多，很容易让人感到困惑。例如，您知道最小预览、标准预览和 1:1 预览之间的区别吗？您知道智能预览的作用是什么，或者为什么 1:1 预览在“修改照片”模块中毫无用处吗？

在本文中，我将分享您需要了解的有关预览的所有信息，包括：

  • 为什么 Lightroom 使用预览（而 Photoshop 不使用预览）
  • 6 种预览类型及其对图像编辑的作用
  • 如何在 Lightroom 中轻松构建预览

完成后，您将成为预览专家。让我们开始吧！

Lightroom 为什么要构建预览？

Lightroom 中的每个文件都有预览 - 但为什么呢？当其他程序（包括 Photoshop）根本不使用预览时，为什么有必要这样做？

它与 Lightroom 独特的图像编辑形式（称为非破坏性编辑）有关。您会发现，当您在 Lightroom 中编辑图像时（例如，当您提高曝光度或增加锐化度时），该软件不会直接更改照片的像素。相反，Lightroom 将这些编辑的记录存储在自己的数据库中。每次您查看照片时，Lightroom 都会访问该文件的数据库记录，然后提供包含所有编辑内容的预览。

换句话说，无论您对照片进行多大程度的编辑，Lightroom 都会保持原始文件不变。它使用预览来显示调整。然后，当您导出图像时，您将获得一个包含所有编辑内容的全新文件。

Lightroom 库模块中的预览

Lightroom Library 模块使用预览来显示您的照片，以便您可以查看、缩放、评级和标记它们。

请注意，您可以在库中构建多种类型的预览，每种预览都提供略有不同的功能：

  • 最少预览
  • 嵌入式和 Sidecar 预览
  • 标准预览
  • 1:1 预览

还有第五种类型的预览，即智能预览，我将在本文的其他地方讨论它。

最少预览

最小预览是 Lightroom 提供的最小预览。

使用最小预览（与列表中的其他选项相反）将节省空间，并且 Lightroom 可以快速添加最小预览（它们实际上直接来自原始图像文件）。但结果不会是高质量的。

因此，如果您需要导入数百张照片并且您很匆忙，那么最小预览可能会有意义。稍后，当您查看和编辑图像时，Lightroom 将花时间创建更大的预览。

不幸的是，创建更大的预览会消耗处理能力。因此，虽然最小预览可能允许在开始时更快地导入，但如果您想以尽可能高的质量查看照片而没有延迟，请考虑使用不同的预览类型。

嵌入式和 Sidecar 预览

与最小预览一样，Lightroom 的嵌入式和 Sidecar 预览直接来自原始图像文件。它们比最小预览大，但也大不了多少，因此可以快速轻松地添加到目录中。

但嵌入式和边车预览不足以进行更仔细的查看或编辑。如果您告诉 Lightroom 使用嵌入式预览，然后浏览图库模块或尝试在修改照片模块中编辑图像，您会注意到延迟，因为 Lightroom 会构建自己的更高质量的预览（请参阅有关标准预览的部分，以下）。

与最小预览一样，当您希望快速导入照片时，嵌入式和边车预览会很有帮助，但如果您计划花费大量时间浏览、组织和编辑文件，则它们并不理想。

标准预览

标准预览专为 Lightroom 的日常使用而设计。它们看起来不错，提供了漂亮的图像渲染，而且没有 1:1 预览那么大（如下所示）。

Lightroom 构建标准预览所需的时间比添加最小预览或嵌入式和边车预览所需的时间更长。这是因为 Lightroom 从头开始​​进行标准预览，而不是从原始图像文件中提取它们。

请注意，如果您觉得标准预览占用了太多空间，或者您只是希望 Lightroom 更快地构建它们，则可以在“目录设置”窗口中调整它们的大小。我建议选择“自动”选项，它告诉 Lightroom 构建与您的显示器分辨率相匹配的预览，但如果您的硬盘空间不足，您始终可以根据需要选择较低分辨率的选项：

标准预览非常棒，尤其是当您计划仅在 Lightroom 中查看照片时。唯一的问题是标准预览并不是为放大特写视图而设计的。如果您从标准预览开始，然后放大，Lightroom 会被迫构建 1:1 预览，这可能会导致延迟。

说到 1:1 预览：

1:1 预览

1:1 预览是 Lightroom 最高质量的图像查看选项，因为它们是全尺寸预览，可让您放大到 100%。它们的建造时间也最长。

换句话说，如果你告诉 Lightroom 构建 1:1 预览，这将需要很长时间- 但之后浏览照片时，你可以零延迟放大。

1:1 预览的另一个缺点是占用大量硬盘空间。 Lightroom 通过在设定的时间后丢弃预览文件来处理此问题。默认值为 30 天，但如果需要，您可以在目录设置中更改该设置：

如果您喜欢像素窥视，那么提前生成 1:1 预览可能确实有意义。这样，您就不必等待 Lightroom 制作文件。另一方面，如果您很少使用 Lightroom 的缩放功能，则可能需要坚持使用标准预览并仅根据需要创建 1:1 预览。

如何在库模块中构建正确的预览

我已经谈论了很多这些不同的 Lightroom 预览，但实际上如何构建它们呢？

有几种方法，但最简单的方法是在导入时选择所需的预览类型。在导入对话框的右侧，Lightroom 允许您从“构建预览”下拉列表中进行选择：

请记住：如果您对低分辨率预览感到满意（并且稍后查看照片时出现延迟），请使用最小或嵌入式预览。否则，选择标准或 1:1。

顺便说一句，如果您最初创建的预览太小，并且决定希望 Lightroom 生成较大的文件，则可以随时选择“库”>;“预览” ，然后指示 Lightroom 构建标准或 1:1 预览。

智能预览

智能预览是一种高质量、高度压缩的预览，它与上面讨论的选项不同，因为它可以在“修改照片”模块中使用。

您会看到，即使在生成标准和1：1预览之后，也无法在开发模块中编辑，而无需访问原始图像文件。但是，如果您创建了智能预览，则可以编辑图像 - 即使包含原始文件的硬盘驱动器未连接到计算机。

此功能使您可以在旅行时使用智能预览来编辑。您所需要的只是一台笔记本电脑，Lightroom目录的副本，包含库模块预览的预览文件和Smart Previews。

请注意，您可以在导入时创建智能预览：

尽管您还可以在以后生成Smart Preview，但只需选择照片，然后点击库>; Previews>;“构建Smart Previews” 。

开发模块中的Lightroom预览

当您从库模块切换到开发模块时，Lightroom使用不同的预览来显示您的图像。 Lightroom提供了高质量的预览，可让您看到诸如锐化， 降噪和肖像修饰等动作的结果。

请注意，开发模块预览是缓存的，而不是保存在预览文件中；否则，每次进行调整时，Lightroom都需要生成一个新的预览，这将迅速吞噬您的大部分硬盘空间。

现在，在图书馆模块中创建1：1预览对开发模块中的Lightroom呈现预览的速度没有影响。但是，如果存在照片的智能预览，Lightroom使用它而不是呈现开发模块预览 - 在以下任何一种情况下：

  1. 包含原始照片文件的硬盘驱动器与计算机断开。
  2. 您的Lightroom CC 2015.7或Lightroom 6.7或更高版本，包含原始照片文件的硬盘驱动器已连接到计算机，并且您具有使用Smart Previews而不是原始图像，以启用偏好中的图像编辑优先级（请参见下文）。请注意，如果将Lightroom放大为1：1，则将停止使用Smart Preview，并将呈现全尺寸预览。

SMART预览小于全尺寸预览，因此在开发模块中使用智能预览时，Lightroom可以更快地运行。速度提高可能非常重要。如果您不经常以100％放大倍率放大照片，那么优先使用智能预览的好处是相当大的。

您应该使用哪些Lightroom预览？

Lightroom的预览有些令人困惑，尤其是对于初学者而言。因此，通过分享不同情况的硬性建议，我将变得轻松。

将图像导入Lightroom时，请选择标准或1：1预览。如果您打算在图书馆模块中查看图像时放大图像，则绝对想选择1：1的预览。否则，选择标准。

如果您在旅行时经常编辑图像，还可以在开发模块中勾选构建Smart Previews选项。而且，如果您在编辑时很少缩放到100％，请在Lightroom首选项中选择使用Smart Previews，而不是用于图像编辑选项的原件。

当我第一次开始认真对待摄影时，我不知道光圈，快门速度和ISO的意思是什么。我根本不知道自己在做什么，但是每个人都告诉我，应该不惜一切代价避免相机的自动模式。结果，我直接进入YouTube教程和在线文章，内容涉及如何摆脱相机上可怕的自动模式设置。毕竟，没有认真的摄影师会使用自动捕获死亡……对吗？

多年后，我可以自信地告诉你，事实不是黑白的。自动模式虽然经常被在线评论者和受欢迎的YouTube摄影师嘲笑，但并不是某些人声称的现代摄影的祸害。虽然这可能不是获得所需的精确图片的最佳方法，而学习手动拍摄是提高摄影师技能的有意义且非常有益的方法，但使用自动使用并没有本质上的错误。

实际上，自动模式带来了一些明显的好处。在本文中，我解释了什么是自动模式并探索其主要优势。当您的相机设置为自动时，我还分享了一些照片创意，这些照片想法非常有效。

到阅读完成时，您希望您会理解为什么如果将昂贵的相机设置为熟悉的绿色自动设置，为什么不应该感到难过！

什么是摄影中的自动模式？

自动模式正好按照声音的方式工作：它可以使您的摄像头完全控制其各种设置，包括ISO ， 光圈， 快门速度， 自动对焦模式，甚至闪光灯。

因此，将相机设置为自动模式后，您的相机可以完成所有繁重的起伏，而您只是指向并射击。

许多高级摄影师批评自动模式，主要是因为它阻止您仔细选择获得特定艺术结果所需的设置。但是，正如我在本文中所建议的那样，自动模式确实具有其位置，并且可能非常有用 - 尤其是对于完整的初学者。

为什么自动模式可以很好

是什么使汽车成为有价值的相机模式？这是其最重要的一些好处：

1.自动通常只起作用

作为摄影师，您比相机要拍摄的图片要好得多。

但是，您可能不知道如何使相机做您想做的事。在这种情况下， 手动模式可能是主要的分散注意力，而自动模式实际上可以确保您制作要创建的图像。

摄影师有时会谈论果断的时刻，这是一个著名街头摄影师Henri Cartier-Bresson使用的术语，以描述框架中所有元素融合在一起以形成完美的摄影机会的瞬间。不幸的是，许多业余摄影师渴望观看那些决定性的时刻，因为他们摆弄了光圈控制和思考快门速度。

我全力以赴地了解如何使用相机，但是有时候将相机放在自动模式下并让它为您完成所有努力工作是很不错的。

另外，现代相机充满了各种高科技增强功能，并且对内置自动模式进行了一系列稳定的改进。因此，在大多数情况下，自动拍摄将为您提供适合您需求的曝光图片。不利的一面是，您的相机在选择光圈，快门速度和ISO时可能会做出令人沮丧的选择（如果没有足够的光线，您可能会看到弹出式弹出式闪光灯后部的丑陋头部）。

但是，如果您不介意相机做出的创意决定，或者您只是不想学习曝光三角形的复杂性，那么，一定要以自动模式进行拍摄。毕竟，这是关于图片的 - 如果您对结果感到满意，那为什么不选择呢？

2.自动让您专注于场景

当您拿出相机记录片刻，内存或特殊事件时，通常会有很多事情发生。可能会有人，孩子，音乐，动物，风，雨，或者是这些元素的组合（除了更多）。

一位经验丰富的摄影师将确切知道如何设置相机以获取所需的图片，并知道要调整哪些设置和更改以获取正确的图像。但是，即使经验丰富的摄影师发生了这么多事情，也可能会感到不知所措 - 对于休闲摄影师来说，情况甚至更糟。

当自动模式成为您最好的朋友时，这是这样的时候。不要对使用它感到尴尬；相反，公开拥抱那种舒适的环境！自动将帮助您获得想要的镜头而不会感到不知所措。而且，如果您的相机照顾它的设置，它可以使您腾出关注真正重要的事情：时刻本身。

3.自动将阻止您缺少关键镜头

大多数摄影师的低点是什么？当他们意识到自己只是错过了镜头时，那些时刻 - 伴随的下沉感。 （甚至众所周知，摄影退伍军人都会不时离开镜头帽！）

如果您只是开始摄影或试图提高技能，那么使用光圈控件来摆弄或试图确定特定场景的正确计量模式，这足以使您想沮丧地将相机扔到窗户上。很容易错过一张精美的照片，因为您正在使用相机设置来搏斗，并在单击快门之前尝试将其弄清楚。

相比之下，Auto可以释放您拍照，同时也欣赏您周围的体验。不用担心ISO，试图找出使用快门速度，或者想知道您是否需要使用闪光灯，而是在使用自动模式时不必深入思考；它将为您照顾所有这些设置（以及更多）。

正如我上面提到的那样，权衡是结果可能不是您想要的。但是至少您会带走一些漂亮的照片，同时也可以自由与其他人交谈，参加现场并在此刻出现。

4.自动可以帮助您了解相机

想要了解更多有关相机和摄影的人的最大入境障碍之一是所有令人困惑的技术细节。了解曝光的基本要素足以使大多数人游泳！最重要的是，还有其他考虑因素： 白平衡，焦距，百万像素等。清单还在继续，这使摄影比邀请更加疏远。

幸运的是，以自动模式拍摄是将脚趾浸入摄影更复杂方面的好方法，只要您不介意做一些额外的腿部工作。

您会看到，嵌入每张图片的元数据中是一大批被称为EXIF数据的信息。而且大多数图像编辑程序都可以让您查看此EXIF数据，以了解有关每个图像的技术基础的更多信息。

如果您使用自动模式拍摄图片，则将关键细节（包括光圈，快门速度和ISO）保存在Exif数据中，以及许多其他信息（例如摄像机模型，闪光灯射击）以及计量模式（Metering Mode）被使用了。查看照片的EXIF数据是了解摄影技术方面的绝佳方法，因此您可以更好地了解如何拍摄图片。这几乎就像拍电影，观看幕后奖励功能或听取导演的评论，因为它使您了解了为获得最终结果做出的创造性决定。

一个快速提示：如果您想在手动模式或相机上的半自动模式中更认真地拍摄，请尝试使用自动拍摄，然后使用EXIF数据手动复制镜头。然后通过调整曝光设置来实验；这样，您可以看到调整这些值如何影响最终图像。

不过要小心！您对相机的设置越来越多，您就会对摄影环境的更大世界变得更感兴趣 - 您很快就会理解如何以您从未想过的方式创造性地控制相机！

您可以使用自动模式捕获的图像

正如我在本文中强调的那样，自动模式可能是享受摄影艺术而不会陷入技术细节的好方法。在本节中，我向您展示了如何使用自动创建五张不同的美丽照片，首先是：

1.散景的肖像

即使您正在自动拍摄，也要拍摄具有美丽模糊背景（也称为Bokeh ）的肖像实际上很容易。

我假设您有一个18-55mm的套件镜头，但是如果您的远摄镜头缩放到200mm或300mm，那就更好了！

只需将相机设置为自动，请确保您的受试者站在相对均匀的区域（例如树林）的前面，然后要求它们向前走，直到距离背景距离很远。一路缩小镜头，以提高散景效果。然后拍照！

真的很简单。您可以在金色时光的光线下创建精美的散景肖像，但是柔软的阴天的天空在上面的图像中产生了美丽的结果！

2.黄金小时的自然照片

许多人喜欢拍摄鲜花和大自然，我很高兴地告诉您，您绝对可以使用相机的自动模式捕获出色的自然照片。但是，您必须使用正确的方法！

首先，确保在灯光正确时拍摄。您会看到，严酷的下午光线很少是拍摄植物，景观或野生动植物的最佳时间。光线很强烈，阴影很刺耳，所产生的图像通常看起来单调且暴露不佳。

尝试在黄金时段拍摄大自然照片！ （在这里，我说的是日出之后和日落之前的两个小时。）温暖的灯光看起来更令人愉悦，而低调的阳光会产生更加均匀的效果。即使在自动模式下，您也可能会对照片的结果感到满意！

3.动作镜头

如果您在灯光变暗时以自动模式拍照（例如，内部或晚上），您可能会出现模糊的照片，尤其是当您的受试者移动时。这是因为您的相机会试图通过降低快门速度来弥补有限的光线，而当您使用自动时，您就无法说出其他方式。

幸运的是，您可以在使用Auto时捕获移动受试者的大头钉图像 - 您只需要使用大量光来冻结动作！

每个人都喜欢拍摄轮廓镜头，但是对于大多数初学者来说，当您想要时，相机似乎从未产生剪影 - 当您不想要剪影时，它似乎永远不会停止！

每当您不想要剪影时，请确保主要的光源来自您后面，并从前面击中主题。

5.令人垂涎的食物照片

许多博客作者购买了一台昂贵的相机，并对结果感到失望。但是，可以在汽车上拍摄不错的食物照片吗？根据我的经验，是的！您只需要使用周到的方法即可。

您会看到，美食照片的关键是轻。通常，您想要明亮但散布的照明，并且希望它来自食物旁或后面以带出质地。 （拍照时，窗户是一个很好的光源！）

变得完美可能有些棘手，但是如果您调整角度并拍摄少量镜头，通常会取得好结果！如果灯光相对较弱 - 就像在餐厅或厨房柜台拍摄时通常一样 - 您可能需要使用三脚架来确保镜头呈锋利。

当然，对相机有更多的控制是很好的，但是通过放弃控制并使用自动，您可以自由地专注于对您更重要的其他事物。如果听起来像您，请将相机模式拨号放在那个小的绿色正方形上，然后单击。

这篇文章于2024年2月在杰里米·弗林特（Jeremy Flint），安妮·麦金内尔（Anne McKinnell）和杰伊姆斯·登普西（Jaymes Dempsey）的贡献中进行了更新。

野生动植物摄影可能令人振奋，但这并非没有挑战。通过镜头捕捉野生动植物的本质不仅需要相机和一个有趣的主题。这是耐心，时机，技术和知识的融合 - 精通的道路充满了陷阱，可以阻止您成为您可以成为最好的野生动植物摄影师。

许多初学者充满热情地深入研究野生动植物摄影，但发现自己对模糊或不印象的图像感到沮丧。这些失败通常源于常见错误，尽管很容易被忽视，但对照片的结果产生了重大影响。尽早识别并避免这些错误可以大大提高您的图像质量 - 这就是本文的所在地！

在下面，我分享了最常见的野生动植物摄影错误，也可以解释您应该做的更改，以确保您永远不会（或至少很少！）错过那个完美的镜头。

准备提升射击了吗？让我们开始吧！

1.不进行研究

野生动物可能很难找到，它们并不总是您想要的。在您可以拍摄照片之前，您必须学习一些有关如何找到它们的知识 - 否则，您会带着空的存储卡回家。

知道你的动物

您周围有哪种类型的动物？在您外出射击之前，请了解自己是谁，他们吃什么，他们什么时候睡觉以及他们喜欢在哪里放松。例如，如果您正在拍摄鹿，则可以在您所在地区发现的研究以及他们喜欢的栖息地。知道动物会如何反应，何时以及何时受到威胁 - 他们会战斗还是逃跑也很重要吗？

知道季节

在一年中的不同时间，有些动物会更加活跃，尤其是在秋天，当它们寻找冬天的食物时，在春季，当一些动物摆脱了冬眠时。注意不同的季节，并考虑您打算用相机前进时您的目标对象是否会活跃。

露营

我的意思不是一夜之间（除非您喜欢），但是找到一个受欢迎的地区（可能是有水，食物，阴影或庇护所）通常是一种非常有效的做法，动物喜欢聚集。将相机放在附近的三脚架上，然后在某些树木或刷子中掩饰自己（一些摄影师可以购买或建造盲人以掩盖他们的存在）。

要有耐心

动物按照自己的日程安排工作，因此不要试图在其他约会之间进行射击课程。很棒的照片需要时间，您必须让大自然以自己的节奏展开。许多动物很容易受到恐惧，因此保持安静，仍然不起眼，将有助于使它们放松。

2.射击不安

我们没有什么都不称其为“野生动植物” - 您可以犯的最大错误是偶然地遭受的。动物没有适应礼貌的社会，如果您在错误的时间或错误的方式捕获它们，则可能是相当粗糙的客户。他们大部分醒着的生活都在觅食，一顿饭后会很快变得丑陋。永远不要遇到午餐（除非您想取代它！）。

不要直接接近野生动物，如果他们看到您，请避免看着它们，因为这通常是侵略的标志。如果您需要靠近，请保持低调并以宽阔的锯齿形模式移动，以避免吓到动物。

请注意交配季节（或“车辙季节”）是针对您要拍摄的动物类型的。一年中的这个时候，雄性哺乳动物充满了睾丸激素，可能是侵略性，暴力和非常危险的。避免在这些时候拍照。同样，找出何时可能要分娩并抚养年轻的动物。我们都知道在妈妈熊和她的幼崽之间有多么风险！

每当您与野生动植物打交道时，请始终记住，任何生物在被挑衅时都可能很危险，并且要以最大的谨慎和尊重来对待动物及其栖息地非常重要。

3.使用功能不足的装备

您在野生动植物摄影中使用的装备可以使您能够捕捉自然界中那些短暂的时刻的能力。初学者面临选择可负担性和性能之间选择的困境，因此通常购买功能较低的设备。这种折衷可能会导致挫败感和不满，因为这是交易：野生动植物摄影，比几乎任何其他类型都需要大量投资以获得最佳效果。

选择将耐用性与高性能结合起来的相机至关重要，尤其是如果您打算在充满挑战的天气条件下拍摄。具有快速自动对焦和高速爆发模式的相机对于野生动植物摄影是必不可少的。能够以每秒8帧或更高的射击射击使您可以捕获运动序列，从而确保您不会错过高峰动作射击。

同样，镜头的选择至关重要。对于大多数野生动植物摄影，最小焦距为300mm的镜头是必不可少的，而较长的焦距（如400mm或更长时间）是理想的选择，如果您想捕获较小或更遥远的受试者。

镜头可以聚焦的速度几乎与其焦距一样重要。如果自动对焦速度非常慢，您将努力捕捉令人叹为观止的动作。此外，提供宽最大光圈的镜头（例如f/2.8或f/4）可以是在弱光条件下改变游戏规则的镜头，从而使快门速度更快并降低了运动模糊的风险。最后，与摄像机一样，耐用性是另一个因素。设备需要承受户外摄影的严谨性！

4.未能考虑光

光在摄影中起着关键作用，在拍摄野生动植物时，这同样是正确的。光的质量会极大地影响图像的结果，不仅影响了曝光，还影响了照片的心情和感觉。许多初学者的野生动植物摄影师很想在中午冒险，被太阳的亮度所吸引。但是，这可能会导致带有刺耳的阴影和夸张的亮点的图像，从而抢开其自然美和深度的场景。

在日出和日落之前的黄金小时是出于某种原因在专业野生动植物射击者中享誉盛名的。在这些时期，太阳在天空中的较低位置会呈现出柔软，温暖的光芒，会产生非凡的效果。另外，在这几个小时内，野生动植物倾向于更加活跃，为摄影师提供了以最佳光线捕捉动态镜头的机会。

注意光的方向同样重要。通过定位自己来实现的前景，使您的阴影指向主题，可以提供甚至可以提供照明。这个照明方向对于突出细节特别有效，这是许多野生动植物摄影师的首选选择。

当然，您可以从任何角度捕获出色的野生动植物镜头，但是当您刚开始时，Frontlight是一个很棒的选择。不管您如何进行，理解和利用光线的细微差别都可以将您的野生动植物摄影从好处提高到伟大！

5.捕获模糊的图像

模糊有多种形式。例如，您的整个图像可能由于相机震动而模糊，这是由于野生动植物摄影所需的较长焦距而放大的问题。

在景观摄影中，使用三脚架是防止相机震动的好技术，但是在拍摄野生动植物时，三脚架并不那么实用。野生动植物摄影需要更活跃的拍摄风格 - 您将不断地四处移动 - 因此，除非您使用的镜头太大而无法舒适地保持，否则请忘记三脚架。另外，由于动物总是在运动，因此无论如何您都需要快门的速度。这使我进入了第一种对抗摄像机摇摇的方法：使用非常快的快门速度。

在景观摄影中，通常使用镜头至少1/焦距的快门速度。但是通常，在拍摄野生动植物时，由于动物总是在运动时（即使它们似乎站着不动），这将是不够快的。为了避免失望，您需要使用更快的快门速度来冻结自己的运动和动物的运动。

拍摄野生动植物时，这是我的经验法则：如果动物似乎静止不动，请使用1/500的快门速度。而且，如果动物移动，则必须根据其速度调整快门速度。我建议至少1/1000（如果动物以超高速度移动，则更快）。

使用具有图像稳定的镜头也将有助于防止由于摄像机震动而导致的模糊。此外，正如我在上一节中提到的那样，具有宽最大光圈（例如f/2.8或f/4）的镜头将使更多点亮，从而使您可以使用更快的快门速度。相关的是，具有令人印象深刻的高ISO性能的相机将使您在不显着降低图像质量的情况下增强ISO。所有这些选项都将使您能够更快的曝光率，并获得更好的结果。

第二种模糊是焦点模糊。这是由于您的相机无法集中精力的原因，这可能是因为您的受试者正在移动并且AF电机感到困惑。某些相机和镜头的自动对焦系统比其他摄像头系统具有出色的自动对焦系统，但是无论您拥有什么，您都可以通过将相机设置为连续的焦点模式，通常称为AF-C（Nikon）或AI Servo（佳能）。此设置将使您能够在框架中跟踪对象的运动，并更快，准确地集中精力。

6.没有准备

我们都去过那里。您会看到完美的镜头，构图并击中百叶窗。但是到相机聚焦并进行了曝光时，动物已经移动，您最终得到的就是完美射击后的第二个。

有两种方法可以避免这种伤心欲绝：

预期

这是一种只能随练习和敏锐的眼睛而来的技能。如果您可以学会查看何时即将发生完美的时刻，而不是在发生何时发生的情况下，则可以在高峰时刻直接击中快门，并使相机在合适的时间捕捉。

连拍

当动物运动时，您将通过使用连续拍摄模式（也称为“驱动模式”或“爆发模式”）获得最佳的机会。这样，您可以每秒拍摄几张图像，然后选择最成功的图像。

高端数码单反相机和无反光镜相机的最高射击速度将更快，但是无论您拥有哪种相机，都有一些东西有助于获得最高的连续射击率。

一个是快速的存储卡 - 卡具有他们在以上操作的一定速度，更快的卡将确保您的相机不会陷入困境以节省图像。

另一个是充满电的电池 - 随着果汁的排水，相机可能会变得迟钝，因此，在相机袋中保留一两个额外的电池是个好主意。为了获得最终的性能，您可以购买适合相机上的电池夹。这同时容纳了两个电池，以最大程度的速度。

7.距离不够近

很难接近野生动物 - 它们很容易被吓到。因此，许多野生动植物的照片比野生动植物更荒野，动物在其环境中成为一个小斑点。

在某些情况下，这可能是有效的，但是在大多数情况下，您希望该动物在框架中足够大，以查看其眼睛的细节。这是一个好的远摄镜头可以真正帮助您的地方。使用较长的焦距（超过300mm）将使您保持距离，同时仍填充框架。

您可能还考虑了不同的拍摄方法；例如，如果您可以提前确定动物的行为，则有时可以躺在等待中，直到它足够接近框架的照片。

常见的野生动物摄影错误：最后一句话

野生动植物摄影需要耐心，技巧，正确的设备等。而且，如果您积极主动，并且避免了常见的错误 - 例如忽略光质量或使用不足的装备 - 您可以快速改善照片！

通过奉献，练习以及对我上面分享的错误学习的承诺，您可以将野生动植物摄影从模糊的快照转变为对自然热情的有力表达。快乐拍照！

      The post 12 Tips for Capturing the Decisive Moment in Street Photography appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Sebastian Jacobitz .

      This article was updated in February 2024 with contributions from Sebastian Jacobitz, Elizabeth Halford , Andrew Hind , and Darlene Hildebrandt .

      Street photographers love to talk about the “decisive moment,” that slice of time when a scene reaches its compositional climax. But successfully capturing the perfect decisive moment is difficult – and without a careful strategy, it's often impossible.

      I've been doing street photography for years, and over time, I've developed a handful of tricks and techniques that'll increase your chances of nailing that decisive moment. Below, I share those tips – and I promise: If you follow my advice and you spend enough time out in the street, then you'll create plenty of decisive-moment style photos.

      让我们开始吧！

      1. Become quicker with your camera

      While slow, deliberate photography is often relaxing, the street is not a place where you can slack off and take all the time in the world to grab a shot. There is no second chance to catch candid scenes. A decisive moment can last for five, three, or just one second and then be gone forever.

      If you don't catch it in time, you'll lose it for eternity.

      Street photography is a two-step process. Yes, you must be able to spot potential scenes of interest as they occur, but you must also raise your camera, dial in the right settings , and press the shutter button. If you're not intimately familiar with your gear, then you'll fail – no matter your decisive-moment instincts.

      So spend some time learning the ins and outs of your equipment. Make sure you're aware of all necessary camera settings and how to adjust them on the fly. Know the best methods for acquiring focus (I'd encourage you to try zone focusing ), know how to change your shutter speed , aperture , and ISO without looking, and know how to adjust your camera's burst mode speeds .

      That way, when you see a decisive moment occurring, you can instantly lift your camera to your eye and hit that shutter button!

      2. When possible, get set up in advance

      While you can capture decisive-moment style shots with any camera, for the best results, you'll want to use the right camera, and you'll also want to be sure that it's set up correctly.

      The best decisive-moment cameras are quick, with virtually no shutter lag at all. You'll also need to get used to timing your shutter actuations. This can be done with practice, by repeatedly photographing moving objects, such as passing cars or bikes, until you've completely gotten the feel of the timing, and speed of the shutter release. This is vital, as the coordination between your eye, the shutter release, and the camera needs to be instinctive, to achieve the split second timing that's needed.

      You might find that shooting with a prime lens is faster , as well. Using a zoom will inevitably waste precious seconds zooming in and out; it's often quicker to just physically move . You might also find that the focus on a prime lenses is a bit quicker, and that you compose better with a prime attached to the camera, rather than a zoom.

      As far as camera settings are concerned, again, it's all about anticipation. Set up the camera, wait, and shoot. Often this will mean using a number of auto controls – try using auto ISO, auto white balance, and generally shoot in Aperture Priority mode. For fast-paced street photography, the moment is far more important than your choice of depth of field, and even having the camera on Program mode is okay. It's all about emotion and expression, timing and anticipation, and the fewer distractions you have to achieve this goal, the better. If you are a manual shooter, then setting the exposure in advance is critical.

      Finally, it's also worth mentioning, that having a camera that writes to the memory card reasonably quickly is important too. You'll likely need to fire off several shots relatively rapidly, and waiting for the camera to write the card is a pain. Often buying faster, higher-quality cards is the answer!

      3. Get in the zone

      The best way to capture decisive moments is to spot interesting scenes as they're occurring (predicting them in advance is even better!). But to do this with consistency, you need to have the right mindset.

      Specifically, you must be focused . You've got to cast out your attention and keep your head on the swivel, looking around for opportunities. Just walking in a good location while thinking about work or home life won't land you the money shots. To absorb the chaotic environment and notice decisive moments, you need to concentrate.

      I'd encourage you to pause before you step out onto the streets. Take a deep breath, and wipe away any distracting thoughts. Then, when you walk out the door, you'll be ready to capture beautiful moments as they appear.

      By the way, there are a lot of distractions in the modern world. If you have the option, turn off your phone before you shoot and leave your gadgets and gizmos (such as your smartwatch) at home. Remember: The more focused you are, the better you'll do!

      Also, don't get too distracted by your street photography camera . It's a tool that helps you capture your vision, nothing more. You don't need to look at every image you take, and you don't need to spend long seconds agonizing over each setting (see the previous tip!). If this becomes an issue, try using a film camera. The minimalism may help you get in the zone.

      4. Don't be afraid to do some pre-planning

      As you head out, think about where the type of pictures you want to capture, and consider where they're most likely to happen. It's often a bad idea to randomly go out looking for photographs, especially when you're starting out; you really have to put yourself in the best situation, at the best time, to increase your chances of getting the pictures you're after.

      For instance, you'll probably want to head out in the middle of the day, maybe on a weekend, when the streets are more likely to be filled with people. There will be many more interactions, and your chances of success are higher. It all begins with deciding exactly what type of pictures you want, and where the most likely place are that you will get them.

      Once you are in place, pre-visualizing the types of shots you want will give you focus and purpose. If you're photographing at an outdoor market, for example, how about setting yourself the task of photographing human connections, maybe as people are chatting, handing over money or goods, etc? Or how about looking for interesting juxtapositions between shop window displays and people standing or passing in front of them?

      This may all sound rather prescriptive, but by setting yourself some parameters, you'll get your creative juices flowing, focus your attention, and increase your chances of success. There's nothing worse than not knowing what you want and randomly taking pictures just waiting for something to happen.

      5. Overcome your fear

      Once you spot the perfect scene, you'll need to translate it into a photograph – but if you're afraid to get close or to raise the camera to your eye, you'll find your creative freedom restricted. (And if you're deeply afraid, you may struggle to see interesting moments in the first place. Not good!)

      In other words, if you want to be a great decisive moment photographer, you must get over your anxiety . There's no need to be afraid of strangers! Thanks to my years of experience, I can assure you that nothing truly bad will happen to you – as long as you use common sense. Don't go around flashing people in dangerous areas, and you'll do just fine.

      In reality, you may occasionally have someone ask you to delete a picture.差不多就这样了。 And as long as you shoot in a bigger city, even that won't happen very often.

      Honestly, fear of the streets is mostly irrational. It's your mind playing tricks on you! At the same time, everyone feels uncomfortable when they first start out on the street. We're all conditioned to avoid invading the private space of others. But the best street photographers get past this discomfort, and they reach a point where they can shoot without feeling intense anxiety.

      To overcome your fear, I'd recommend asking everyone you pass for a street portrait . Most people will be relaxed, and you'll eventually get rejected – which will show you that it isn't the end of the world .合理？

      6. Perfect your compositional skills

      The decisive moment is all about composition – so if you don't have strong compositional instincts, you'll struggle to notice the best scenes even if they're right in front of your eyes .

      Plus, it's important that you learn how to quickly position yourself and frame the scene for the best result, both of which rely heavily on composition.

      In my experience, a huge number of images are ruined because the composition is slightly off – images that would've otherwise turned out amazing. I know that street photography is often seen as a genre of freedom. But when it comes to aesthetics, there are certain arrangements that look more pleasant than others.

      If you're relatively unfamiliar with composition, then I'd encourage you to start with the rule of thirds . It'll help you position your main subjects in a way that appears both balanced and dynamic.

      I'd also suggest using leading lines ; a line or two that points toward your subject will guide the viewer's eye in the right direction. And if you want to really take your compositions to the next level, try incorporating layers into your images. If you can combine an interesting foreground subject with an interesting background scene, your images will turn out so much better.

      Pro tip: Find some street photographers you like and study their images. Ask yourself: What makes this composition compelling? How did the photographer balance objects throughout the frame? Did they use the rule of thirds? Leading lines? The golden ratio? Over time, you'll start to internalize these different compositional guidelines, and you'll get better and better at applying them when you're out shooting.

      7. Work the scene

      The master of decisive-moment street photography, Henri Cartier-Bresson, almost always took several exposures of the same scene or moment. He very rarely got the shot in one take!

      This means that you need to take a number of frames in fairly quick succession – not on continuous (burst) shooting mode, but close enough together to record subtly different expressions, juxtapositions of people in the frame, and changes of angle and composition.

      You should aim to keep moving: try the shot a little to the left, then the right, maybe a step forward or back, or a little higher or lower. Photographing when an interesting scene appears should tire you out, and you should always be in motion. You can then go through the different frames once you're back home and select the strongest image.

      8. Be unobtrusive

      The best street photography shots tend to come from remaining invisible, which is why I don't think that it's a particularly good approach to stalk your subject from behind a huge 400mm lens!

      Instead, it's much better to use something smaller and less intrusive, to be closer to the subject and more involved in what's going on. Consequently people will behave in a much more natural and relaxed way in front of you and your camera.

      Sometimes, people will notice what you're doing, and it's important to remain as non-threatening as possible. This can be as simple as smiling, looking relaxed, keeping your body language open and friendly, and just being respectful of people's personal space. Yes, you're an observer, but you have to observe from a position of being emotionally and physically involved. You'll gain much more acceptance from your subjects, and even if someone does notice your camera, the pictures will be more authentic and natural.

      That's not to say that your presence should influence the scene in any way; it's just that you have to be accepted to be able to photograph people behaving naturally. If your subjects notice you and then do a pose for the camera or just seize up, you won't get good images.

      A great way of making this work is to move in and out of the scene really quickly – essentially this means waiting for a scene to unfold a little distance from you. As an interesting moment is about to happen, walk toward the scene, camera ready to go. Very quickly, shoot as you are close to the action, then continue to walk out of the scene. If you combine this with unobtrusive body language, you can remain essentially invisible.

      9. Get inspired

      If you don't already look at street photography on a regular basis, start doing it right away. Follow photographers on Instagram, set aside time to look at websites, buy some photobooks – just make sure you're spending lots of time contemplating the best work in the genre.

      Because the more you look at great street photos – especially those street photos that rely on decisive moments – the better you'll get at identifying the perfect scenes and opportunities when you're out with your camera.

      Plus, looking at the work of other photographers will offer lots of powerful inspiration. You'll feel more excited to hit the streets, and you may discover ideas for photos that you would've never considered otherwise.

      By the way: The right mood can also help you capture interesting photos. So don't feel like you must only look at pictures; you can also listen to music, watch your favorite movie, or read a good book. As long as it helps you be more creative, it's fair game!

      10. Persevere

      Street photography is a lot of fun, but it's not a discipline that'll offer a quick and low-effort path to great photos. While you can certainly manage to capture beautiful decisive moment shots when you're just starting out, it often takes months and years of work before you can regularly capture stunning images.

      So if you're struggling to get what you want, don't give up. Know that results will come eventually.你只需要练习。

      To accelerate the learning curve, spend plenty of time looking at other photos (as emphasized in previous tips!). And consider forming a group of other photographers who have similar goals. If you can walk the street with other street shooters – especially those with more experience – you'll start to see the world from a new perspective. You'll notice photo opportunities that you would never think of otherwise!

      11. Don't chimp!

      The decisive moment is often slightly later than you'd expect. If you've just captured one shot, you'll often be tempted, during this time, to take a look at the screen (ie, chimp). And that's when the best scene of all will appear and disappear! (This is what I call the chimping effect.)

      Many, many times, I've taken an image, had a quick look down at the screen on the back of the camera, only to realize that I just missed something better.

      So don't look at the screen. Keep your camera ready, and always wait – even if you think you've got the shot.

      Relatedly, you will often miss great shots when you are tired and have given up. You need to keep going and going – I know that the longer I shoot, the more high quality images I will get. I also know that by having a complete break for five minutes or so every hour, I am able to keep quick and alert for longer. It's amazing to consider how, when I give up on a scene, something interesting often seems to just appear!

      12. Stay curious

      However you approach decisive moment street photography, don't lose interest in your environment and in humankind. Cultivate your curiosity, embrace your inner tourist, and look for scenes that might normally seem boring.

      If you're struggling to find subjects to shoot, think back to the last time you were on vacation. Didn't everything seem so interesting? The most mundane places offer lots of opportunities if you have the right mindset. A restaurant, a car, an old door; these might seem boring to a longtime resident, but to a photographer with the right mindset, they offer dozens of outstanding photos!

      One more tip: Don't ever restrict your shooting. It's better to shoot too much than too little! Digital storage is cheap, and missing a decisive moment can be deeply frustrating. So keep your finger on the shutter button, and be ready to shoot at a moment's notice.

      Decisive moment street photography: final words

      Now that you've finished this article, you're ready to capture some decisive moments.

      So remember the tips I've shared. Get out on the street, be mindful, stay focused, and have fun. Over time, the results will follow!

      Capturing the essence of vast landscapes in a two-dimensional frame can be challenging. The key lies in understanding and effectively using 'scale' to bring context and depth to your images. Here, we explore techniques to master scale in landscape photography, transforming your shots from ordinary to extraordinary.

      1. Introduce a Human Element: Incorporating a person in your landscape photo instantly establishes scale. It helps the viewer relate to the enormity of the surroundings, whether it's towering mountains or expansive plains.

      2. Use Familiar Objects: No people around? Use other familiar objects like vehicles, animals, or buildings to offer a sense of scale. A car on a vast mountain road, for instance, can dramatically highlight the scene's magnitude.

      3. Layering and Foreground Elements: Creating layers in your image, with a strong foreground element, adds depth and a sense of scale. This technique allows viewers to visually traverse from the foreground to the distant background, understanding the space between.

      4. Use Wide Lenses: Wide-angle lenses capture more of a scene, emphasizing its vastness. Combining a wide lens with a foreground element exaggerates the perspective, enhancing the sense of scale.

      5. Capture Atmospheric Perspective: This phenomenon, where distant objects appear lighter and less saturated, adds a sense of depth and vastness. Scenes with atmospheric perspective, like fading mountain layers, emphasize the grand scale.

      6. Play with Shadows and Light: Utilizing the interplay of light and shadow, especially during golden hours, adds dimension. Long shadows can illustrate the enormity of elements like trees or mountains.

      7. Use Leading Lines: Leading lines, such as rivers or roads, guide the viewer's eye and illustrate the scale of the landscape. They create a visual journey from the foreground to the horizon.

      8. Drones and Aerial Photography: Drones offer a unique bird's-eye perspective, revealing landscape proportions and patterns unseen from the ground. This fresh viewpoint can showcase scale in an extraordinary way.

      This article was updated in January 2024 with contributions from Kat Landreth, Karthika Gupta , and Jaymes Dempsey .

      Photographing with other people has tons of advantages; it offers new perspectives, helps you improve, and makes your outings more enjoyable.

      But how can you actually find photography friends? While it may take a bit of effort, locating photo buddies isn't as hard as you might think – and in this article, I share my favorite ways to discover friends and active photography groups.

      让我们开始吧！

      1. Take a class

      Lots of universities have photography departments, and you don't need to be a photography major to take a photo class . Some schools even offer weekend short courses (not for credit) for folks who just want to brush up on their skills or learn how to use a digital camera. These can be pretty cheap.谁知道呢？ You might even learn something along the way!

      You can also look for classes conducted by local photography educators; also check the course listings at nearby art centers, community centers, art galleries, libraries, and camera shops.

      Try to be open and friendly during the class sessions. When the class is coming to a close, you can express interest in meeting up with others. In my experience, taking photo classes is a great way to find other folks who want to shoot. I actually just started a club with some people from a class I took earlier this year!

      2. Attend conferences and photography-related events

      There is nothing quite like getting a bunch of photographers in a room to talk shop and discuss the latest and greatest gear and techniques. The energy and the learnings at such events are incredible. Most conferences and events get the best speakers and teachers, so this is a great way to increase your skill set and also meet some of your mentors and peers.

      As someone who has started to speak and teach at conferences and events, I am just as nervous to get up on stage as you might be to come to an event! However, I am so happy to meet and mingle with my people (folks who love photography as much as I do!).

      So go with an open mind and be willing to put yourself out there to make genuine connections and friends.

      3. Just go up and introduce yourself

      Yes, it's simple – but when you're out capturing the beauty of the world, keep your eyes open for fellow photography enthusiasts. If you spot someone with a camera who seems to share the same interests, don't hesitate to approach them! A shared passion is a powerful icebreaker.

      Introducing yourself to another photographer doesn't have to be daunting. You can compliment their gear or ask them about what they're photographing, and if they're interest in engaging, this will open the door to a more in-depth conversation.

      Mention that you're a photographer too (if they can't already tell from your camera!) and express your interest in connecting further. Social media platforms like Instagram are perfect for this because they provide an immediate way to share your work and see theirs.

      Once the initial connection is made, you can always suggest a joint photography outing. Whether it's exploring urban landscapes, chasing the golden hour in the countryside, or setting up a studio shoot, doing photography together can help strengthen your bond. These shared experiences often lead to learning from each other, sharing tips and techniques, and, most importantly, building a friendship!

      4. Browse Meetup.com

      Meetup.com is a website dedicated to group meetups – including photo walks , photography clubs, and photo workshops . Depending on where you live, there might already be a handful of photography groups nearby; just head over to Meetup.com, type in your address, and see what you can find.

      If you identify a group that interests you, click the “Join This Group” button, and check out the upcoming events. Some events – especially the photography workshops – cost a few dollars, but most are free.

      Meetup.com is a great way to meet other photographers without making much of a commitment. And if you can't find a group that caters to your interests, you can always make your own!

      5. Search Facebook groups

      Facebook is full of people who want to become your photography friends. You just don't know it yet!

      The trick is to find local photography groups. Head over to the “Groups” tab, then type in “your location” + “photography.”

      You may not discover any in-person photography meetups or photowalks, but if you find a group for image critiquing and/or sharing, create a brief post. List your photography interests, share your location, and express your desire to meet up with other photographers. With any luck, you'll get plenty of commenters looking to have some photographic fun!

      6. DM local photographers on Instagram

      These days, Instagram draws photographers from across the globe – including, I'll bet, plenty who live near you.

      And thanks to Instagram's tagging features, it's easy to find snappers who like to shoot where you shoot. Simply head over to Instagram and type your location into the search option. You can then see images taken nearby, or you can view hashtags dedicated to nearby towns and cities.

      Find a photographer (or three) whose interests align with your own. Then reach out to them! Instagram offers a direct messaging function, so it shouldn't be hard to strike up a conversation. Ask about their work, their favorite locations, and more. Then consider proposing a meetup. Over time, maybe it'll turn into a regular outing!

      7. Join local camera clubs

      The term “camera club” might bring to mind a bunch of people sitting around a table in a library…

      …but that's not always the case. (Plus, what's wrong with a good old library meeting?)

      These days, camera clubs are still very active, and they're not all round-table discussion groups, either. Plenty of camera clubs offer workshops, group meetups, and photowalk fun. Plus, they're a great way to meet other photographers who have similar interests and live in the general vicinity. If the club doesn't offer any interesting activities, go ahead and make your own .

      How do you find local photography clouds? Try Googling “camera clubs near me” and “photography clubs near me.” See what comes up!

      8. Hang out at your local camera shop

      Camera shops are not just places to buy new gear; they're hubs for the photography community. These stores often attract individuals who are passionate about photography, including the staff. In my experience, many of the folks who work in camera shops are photographers themselves and can offer insights into the latest gear, photography techniques, and local photography spots worth exploring. If you explain that you're looking for likeminded folks to photograph with, they might even be interested in shooting!

      You can also ask if the camera shop offers classes or meetups of any sort – and if they do, make sure to sign up! Plus, the allure of new cameras and lenses is undeniable for any photography enthusiast. While browsing the latest equipment, you might strike up a conversation with someone who shares your excitement, and this shared enthusiasm can be the beginning of a friendship!

      9. Spend time on online photography forums

      If you're looking for in-person photo friends you can shoot and hang out with, this one isn't such a great idea. But some folks don't mind (or even prefer) making online friends – people with whom you can chat about inspiration, share photos, ask for critiques, and so on.

      So check out some online photography forums and websites. Ideally, you'll find a group of photographers who share your interests – for instance, a site like Nature Photographers Network is (as the name suggests) dedicated to nature photography – but more general sites, such as Reddit's r/photography , can also工作。

      You can participate as an active forum member, and if you seem to connect with any of the posters, send them a private message. Ask to see their latest photos, and ask if you can show them yours. See if you can get a regular chat going!

      10. Find local photowalks

      If you live near a major city (or even a smaller one), there may be a photowalk or two that's conducted on a regular basis. These are pretty informal; photowalk members will meet, spend a few hours shooting a location, and maybe even hang out afterward. These photography groups do tend to be more street- and architecture-focused, but you can find nature and landscape photowalks, too.

      Unfortunately, because photowalks tend to be so informal, it can be difficult to track them down in the first place. I'd start with a Google search, but if you can't find anything, spend some time messaging local photographers on Facebook and Instagram. You might also try reaching out to camera stores in the area; sometimes, they may offer a photowalk of their own – and if not, they might be able to point you in the right direction.

      Of course, if you can't find a good photowalk, you can always create your own. I'd recommend setting up a group on Facebook, then inviting local photographers to join. You can also post on local Facebook photography groups. Explain what you've created, how it'll work, then propose a time, a route, and a starting location for your first meetup.

      11. Contact local photographers through their websites

      In the digital age, connecting with fellow photographers has never been easier. If you're seeking more targeted connections, particularly with professionals or hobbyists within your own genre of photography, a simple online search for “[GENRE] photographers near me” can open up a world of possibilities. With any luck, you'll find a host of websites, where you can get inspired with local work – and you can perhaps reach out through the website contact form, start up a conversation, and maybe even share some work of your own.

      If you do decide to reach out, draft a message that explains who you are, touches on how their work has inspired you, and perhaps even share a bit of your own portfolio. It's a gesture that not only demonstrates your genuine interest in their work but also lays the groundwork for a relationship. Should they respond, the conversation can naturally progress towards suggesting a joint shooting session. Of course, it's always important to approach these interactions with respect for the photographer's time and an openness to the possibility of collaboration rather than immediate friendship.

      12. Go to art fairs

      Art fairs offer a vibrant tableau of creativity and culture, and while these events may not always be photography-centric, they frequently feature at least on or two photographers among the exhibitors. This presents an excellent opportunity for you to discover local photographers whose work resonates with your own creative sensibilities!

      Start by conducting a bit of research online to locate art fairs in your vicinity. Once you've found a few interesting fairs, make it a priority to attend.

      Once at the fair, take the time to appreciate the work, and don't hesitate to initiate conversations with the photographers. Discussing their photography can serve as a great icebreaker and may lead to deeper discussions about techniques, inspirations, and experiences!

      As with the other tips for making photography friends, having an earnest conversation can always turn into collaborative opportunities and real friendships. Whether it's planning a joint exhibition, participating in a group project, or simply arranging a casual photo walk, the relationships fostered at art fairs can be hugely valuable! By being proactive and open to new connections, you stand to gain not only new friends but also – if you're lucky – a wealth of inspiration and support.

      How to find photography friends: final words

      Talking and shooting with other photographers can be a very valuable experience. If you're going it alone all the time, then you're missing out!

      So try to find some friends. Seek out photography groups, look for camera clubs, and contact local shooters on Instagram. And above all, have fun!

      The post How to Take Photos Out of a Plane Window (10 Expert Tips) appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Darren Rowse .

      Everyone loves to capture plane-window photos; they're perfect for social media, they tell a great story, plus they capture the excitement of traveling to an amazing photographic destination.

      But taking photos out of a plane window isn't as simple as pointing your camera and tapping the shutter. Instead, if you want to create beautiful, sharp, well-exposed shots , you must use the right settings, wait for the right moment, and create a compelling composition .

      It's all in this article: The 10 tips and techniques you absolutely must know for amazing out-the-window results. That way, the next time you're flying 30,000 feet above the ground, you're ready to immortalize the experience!

      Let's dive right in.

      1. Ask for a window seat

      Securing a window seat is your first step to capturing breathtaking views from the sky. It might seem obvious, but if you want to capture stunning photos from a plane window, it's important to make sure that you have window access!

      The process begins the moment you book your flight. Many airlines allow you to select your seat during this initial stage. If you can't choose a seat right away, don't worry. Check-in time often presents another opportunity to snag that coveted window spot.

      Unfortunately, it's sometimes the case that, despite your best efforts, you might find yourself assigned an aisle seat. If that happens, don't hesitate to ask the gate staff for a seat change. They're often more accommodating than you might expect, especially if you're willing to give up a “better” seat in order to get that window spot. Of course, it's not always guaranteed, but your chances of getting a window seat increase significantly if you try all of these steps!

      By the way, it's also a good idea to consider where you'll be positioned on the plane. If you're seated in the middle of the plane, for instance, the wing might restrict your view and limit your photographic opportunities. Opting for a seat closer to the plane's tail, or in front of the wings, can provide a clearer and more expansive canvas for your aerial shots!

      2. Keep the lens away from the window

      When you're shooting out the window, it's tempting to put your camera's lens right up against the glass. After all, in addition to cutting down on unwanted reflections, this approach steadies the camera, right?

      不完全的。 While pressing the lens on the glass can help with reflections, it actually causes your camera to shake more , not less. Unfortunately, planes vibrate as they fly, and when the plane window touches a part of your lens, it'll transmit those vibrations straight to the camera sensor (which will produce lots of image blur).

      The better strategy is to keep your camera held slightly back. Tuck in your elbows, and if your lens or camera offers image stabilization, make sure the technology is active. To reduce reflections, attach a hood to the lens and position your setup as close to the window as you can get it without any contact.

      (If you don't have a lens hood, you can cup your free hand around the end of the lens or you can cover your camera with a shirt or jacket.)

      While avoiding contact between the lens and the window will reduce camera shake , it won't eliminate it entirely. But if your shutter speed is fast enough, this won't matter; the split-second shutter will capture a sharp shot before the shake has time to cause problems. So boost your shutter speed if you can (and don't be afraid to increase your ISO to ensure you capture a balanced exposure).

      3. Use a camera with a high dynamic range

      Capturing the vast expanse of the sky and the intricate details of clouds requires a camera capable of handling a wide range of light and dark tones. This is where the dynamic range comes into play. Cameras with a high dynamic range do a great job of rendering deep shadows and bright highlights – and as a result, you can photograph stunning scenes with rich details in both the brightest and darkest areas.

      So what kind of camera should you use? Full-frame cameras tend to offer the best dynamic range capabilities, making them ideal for plane-window photography, but not everyone has access to a full-frame camera, and that's perfectly okay. APS-C cameras have a smaller sensor, but they can also do a great job of rendering highlights and shadows!

      Finally, if you opt for the convenience of a smartphone camera, activating the HDR (High Dynamic Range) setting is a must. This feature works by capturing multiple images at different exposures and blending them into one, resulting in photographs that better balance light and shadow.

      4. Keep your setup relatively compact

      While planes can vary in size, you generally won't have a whole lot of room in your seating area, especially if you're on a shorter flight. Bulky DSLRs and large zoom lenses are not only challenging to maneuver in such tight quarters but can also be a source of irritation for you and your fellow passengers, and that's why I always recommend keeping your plane camera setup relatively small. At the end of the day, a compact setup isn't just about convenience – though working with a smaller camera and lens is a lot easier! – it's about being considerate and ensuring you can quickly and easily capture the moments that matter without causing frustration to others.

      Mirrorless cameras have become a favorite among travel photographers for this reason. Their compact size, combined with high-quality imaging capabilities, makes them ideal for capturing stunning aerial shots. As for lenses, I often use a 50mm f/1.8 prime lens when shooting out the plane window; it's lightweight, offers excellent image quality, and its fixed focal length encourages creative compositions. Plus, the 50mm field of view allows for a variety of shots, from detailed landscapes to nuanced interior scenes!

      5. Switch to manual focus

      Cameras often get confused when shooting through glass, especially dirty and/or scratched glass. They try to focus on the glass instead of the subject outside, which is generally not what you want.

      So if your camera has the option, switch to its manual focusing mode . Then slowly adjust the focus point until you get your main subject tack-sharp.

      It can help to take a test shot, then zoom in on your camera LCD. That way, you can check the focus and make adjustments accordingly.

      If your setup doesn't offer a manual focusing option, try putting your camera right up against the glass and focusing on your subject. (If your lens is close enough, the glass shouldn't pose much of a problem.) Then lock the focus, and bring your camera back into position. While shifting the camera will technically cause the plane of focus to shift, as long as your subject is reasonably far from the plane window, this won't make a huge difference, and you'll still end up with a sharp shot!

      (Pro tip: If you use the focus-lock method shared above but you keep capturing out-of-focus shots, try narrowing your aperture to f/8 or so. The resulting deep depth of field should help compensate for the focusing error. ）

      6. Make sure to shoot early and late in the flight

      In my experience, the handful of minutes just after takeoff is the best time to shoot through the plane window.为什么？ A couple of reasons.

      First, once you've been flying for a while, the windows tend to ice up or collect condensation, which will decrease image sharpness and make it tough to focus. When the plane has been on the ground for an extended period, however, the condensation and ice evaporate, giving you a clear(ish) window to work through.

      Second, when you're just taking off, you'll see a huge variety of subjects. You can capture the airport from above (and use it to tell the story of your departure), you can capture rows of houses and cars (which often look delicate and even cute), and you can shoot beautiful buildings (if the airport is reasonably close to a city).

      But as the plane gains altitude, you'll get too high to capture lots of interesting subjects, and you'll struggle to create a compelling composition.

      Of course, you can often find interesting subjects again when the plane starts to land, though you may still have condensation and/or ice to contend with. Why not maximize your time behind the lens and be ready to shoot both during both takeoff and as the plane comes back down to earth?

      7. Wait for the plane to bank

      Once the plane is relatively high in the sky, it can be pretty difficult to take shots of the landscape far below. You may need to position your camera at a steep angle, which can increase the likelihood of reflections and will limit your compositional options.

      Fortunately, planes don't just sit in the sky; every so often, they bank , which – when in the right direction – will give you an opportunity to capture the ground.

      This banking generally happens soon after takeoff and just before landing, and it doesn't last long, so you need to be ready. Carefully set and lock the exposure, and make sure to lock your focus, too (it's fine to tilt your camera so you can focus on the ground).

      Then, when the bank begins, start photographing with abandon. (Your camera's burst mode can be helpful.) Don't stop shooting until the bank is finished!

      8. Turn off your flash

      Planes tend to be dark (especially if you're flying at night), so you might be tempted to turn on your flash. (Alternatively, your camera may sense the limited ambient light and activate the flash automatically.)

      Regardless, make sure to manually switch your flash off .

      For one, a flash certainly won't illuminate the area outside the plane window; no flash is strong enough to have an impact beyond 20 feet or so. And a flash will cause plenty of unpleasant glare and create blinding window reflections, so you won't be able to see out the window and your shots will be ruined.

      If your shots are turning out dark, you have a few options. You can widen your lens aperture, you can boost your ISO, you can add positive exposure compensation , or you can lower your shutter speed. If you're on a long flight, you might also simply consider waiting until things get lighter!

      9. Include points of interest in your compositions

      Scenes outside plane windows can often seem quite spectacular to the eye, but when you try to capture the beauty, you end up with images that are just…boring.

      This is because great photos generally need an anchor point – something that catches the viewer's attention and gets them to engage with the scene.

      So instead of just pointing and shooting, look for a point of interest that draws the eye. This can be anything: a cloud formation, another plane, a coastline, or even a setting sun.

      Then compose your image while keeping that point of interest in mind. Consider using helpful composition guidelines, such as the rule of thirds, the golden spiral, or plain old symmetry, to position your point of interest. And adjust your framing – while looking through the camera viewfinder, if possible – until you get a great result!

      10. Photograph the plane interior

      While the allure of the world outside your window can be mesmerizing, the plane's interior can make for great shots, too. By subtly zooming out, you can frame the majestic views outside with the plane window itself, creating a compelling frame-within-a-frame effect. (This technique not only adds depth to your images but also helps tell the story of your journey!)

      It can also be fun to incorporate elements like tray tables, your outstretched hand, and even other passengers. These shots, combining the interior's coziness with the vastness outside, are absolutely breathtaking, plus they do a great job of emphasizing the wonder that is flight!

      And once you've captured some nice interior-exterior shots, I encourage you to capture a few shots that feature only the interior; you can get super-cool results, especially at night, when everyone is sleeping and the passengers are illuminated by twinkling lights from inside the cabin.
